Erik Wilde (@dret): REST vs. GraphQL: Making the Right Choice

(2) Summary

Most APIs today are using the resource style of REST, but GraphQL still is a trending technology and increasingly considered as a way to design and build APIs. We take a structured look at the differences in style, the differences in use cases, and the differences it takes behind the scenes to make a good choice between REST and GraphQL. The goal of this presentation is not to claim that one approach is better than the other, but to clearly analyze how they differ, why that matters, and how that understanding can help you to make a good choice for your API.

REST vs. GraphQL: A Question of Style

REST vs. GraphQL: A Question of Style Erik Wilde (@dret): REST vs. GraphQL: Making the Right Choice

(7) APIs Crash Course

  • APIs are the connective fabric of modern IT
  • API First is the radical notion to only interact through APIs
    • Every capability has an API that is its only accessible interface
    • The only technical interconnection is through exposing/consuming APIs
    • APIs aligned with business then also become organizational interconnections
  • Microservices take APIs to the next level
    • API implementations need to be self-contained and individually deployable
    • Microservices allow flexible changes, deployment and scaling
  • Getting APIs right becomes an essential part of architecture


REST vs. GraphQL: A Question of Style Erik Wilde (@dret): REST vs. GraphQL: Making the Right Choice

(8) Facebook Apps and API



REST vs. GraphQL: A Question of Style Erik Wilde (@dret): REST vs. GraphQL: Making the Right Choice

(9) Social Graphs are Large and Complex



REST vs. GraphQL: A Question of Style Erik Wilde (@dret): REST vs. GraphQL: Making the Right Choice

(10) API for Facebook Apps

  • Facebook apps did not work well with the existing API
    • Chatty because UX is based on fetching many resources
    • Overfetching because resources are represented in a default way
  • Different ways to address the observed problems
    1. Make REST resources more flexible to allow filtering and/or embedding
    2. Start using the backends-for-frontends pattern for different apps
    3. Create a flexible model that supports queries into the social graph


REST vs. GraphQL: A Question of Style Erik Wilde (@dret): REST vs. GraphQL: Making the Right Choice

(13) GraphQL: Query Style



REST vs. GraphQL: A Question of Style Erik Wilde (@dret): REST vs. GraphQL: Making the Right Choice

(14) GraphQL: A New API Foundation

  • GraphQL [https://graphql.org/] as a query-oriented API language
    • Typically served over HTTP like REST APIs
    • Based on interactions with a single API endpoint
  • Define and expose a data model
    • The API is defined by exposing a data model (and possibly additional operations)
    • Consumers query into the data model (or may use the additional operations)


REST vs. GraphQL: A Question of Style Erik Wilde (@dret): REST vs. GraphQL: Making the Right Choice

(15) GraphQL Request/Response Example



REST vs. GraphQL: A Question of Style Erik Wilde (@dret): REST vs. GraphQL: Making the Right Choice

(16) For Your Consideration…

  • Started by Facebook as a way to optimize chatty API traffic
  • Facebook's public Graph API [https://developers.facebook.com/docs/graph-api/] does not use GraphQL
  • Facebook has centralized governance over all components in the API scenario


Deciding Between REST and GraphQL

Outline (Deciding Between REST and GraphQL)

  1. Introduction [2]
  2. REST vs. GraphQL: A Question of Style [10]
  3. Deciding Between REST and GraphQL [4]
  4. Conclusions [3]
Deciding Between REST and GraphQL Erik Wilde (@dret): REST vs. GraphQL: Making the Right Choice

(18) Your API Landscape

  • Complex and evolving API landscapes are challenging to centralize
  • Varying API scenarios may best be served by various API patterns
  • Enterprise architecture is moving away from integration to interconnection
  • Consider the long-term cost and not just the initial effort


Deciding Between REST and GraphQL Erik Wilde (@dret): REST vs. GraphQL: Making the Right Choice

(19) Data or Workflows?

  • Some services focus on accessing complex data models
    • GraphQL is built around the assumption that an API provides data access
  • Some services are process-oriented with data-driven workflows
    • REST/Hypermedia guides users and is focused on state-changing interactions


Deciding Between REST and GraphQL Erik Wilde (@dret): REST vs. GraphQL: Making the Right Choice

(20) Listen to your Consumers

  • Developer Experience (DX) means to design for API consumers
  • The prototypical GraphQL scenario is to be provided as a back-end for UI consumers
  • GraphiQL [https://github.com/graphql/graphiql] is an interactive GraphQL API Explorer


Deciding Between REST and GraphQL Erik Wilde (@dret): REST vs. GraphQL: Making the Right Choice

(21) Avoid Taking Shortcuts

  • Treat APIs as a central part of your value proposition
  • Resist the temptation to simply expose your implementation
  • Design your API with consumers and their needs in mind


Conclusions

Outline (Conclusions)

  1. Introduction [2]
  2. REST vs. GraphQL: A Question of Style [10]
  3. Deciding Between REST and GraphQL [4]
  4. Conclusions [3]
Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): REST vs. GraphQL: Making the Right Choice

(23) There is no Silver Bullet

  • Choose carefully because breaking API changes should be avoided
  • GraphQL currently is mostly used in tightly coupled scenarios (private APIs)
  • REST is used for the majority of APIs for partner/public consumption
  • Design your API with the consumers and their needs in mind


Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): REST vs. GraphQL: Making the Right Choice
